channel.title: Ultimate Newbie Question
channel.description:
so last time i did java was 4years ago in my highschool, after that i never touched it expect for C last year.
well i really didn't have interest in java before, thus what ever i learned got flushed out the other end when i finished my class.
now i want to learn programing, after of-course i realized it could save tons of time on my computational work.
thus i want to learn java (i have bad scars from C i am still healing from)
so i took up java, starting from the basic, "Hello word"
well sad to say i can't even run it, and the error given by Eclipse, i can make sense.
so this what happens when i try to run hello word
[IMG]http://i39.tinypic.com/2d6nnyv.jpg[/img]
any help java elites?

item.title: Ultimate Newbie Question
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:24, topic:339657”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=436035.msg3204153#msg3204153 date=1273621936]

[quote author=Speljohan link=topic=436035.msg3203492#msg3203492 date=1273550660]

[quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=436035.msg3203373#msg3203373 date=1273539733]

[quote author=Ollie link=topic=436035.msg3203315#msg3203315 date=1273536522]

[quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=436035.msg3203300#msg3203300 date=1273534893]

Blame eclipse for sucking, use IDEA
[/quote]shoot yourself

? IDEA > Eclipse
[/quote]how exactly
[/quote]By not having 500 half-assed, badly implemented plugins, but instead having nearly all extra content officially updated by Jetbrains to comform to high usage standards.
[/quote]Any plugins you don’t like can be disabled. Personally, I used IDEA for about an hour until I came to the conclusion that it was very similar to JCreator (which I used for like 6 months) and dropped it. As opposed to IDEA, eclipse is 100% open source (unlike the ‘ultimate edition’ for idea) and contains integrated features that just completely eliminate IDEA from the competition. The method/variable auto-completion feature, the on-the-fly javadoc parsing (and display of it when using the auto-completion feature), and the advantage that it uses its own compiler and therefore provides much more flexibility than if it were to use javac, for example. Also, the compilation-upon-file-save feature is very useful in my opinion, along with the red (upon error) / yellow (upon warning) underlining in the file. I know other IDEs, like Netbeans, which have very similar features, but I’m quite sure that IDEA doesn’t have all these (if any at all). In addition to that, eclipse is very light-weight in comparison and provides many advantages if you program other languages as well, since with a simple plugin, full support for that language would be integrated. I, for one, use eclipse for developing C/C++ for the reasons above AND because unlike any other C IDEs I know of, eclipse doesn’t force you to use a certain (and possibly outdated) compiler and instead lets you choose the one of your preference.
[/quote]Ahahahahahahaha ur such a fukken idiot, IDEA has everything you mentioned and a lot more. There’s a reason IDEA is industry standard.[/quote]did you forget the ‘as opposed to idea’, also doesn’t have own compiler

Read full topic

Personally, I used IDEA for about an hour until I came to the conclusion that it was very similar to JCreator (which I used for like 6 months) and dropped it. As opposed to IDEA, eclipse is 100% open source (unlike the ‘ultimate edition’ for idea) and contains integrated features that just completely eliminate IDEA from the competition. The method/variable auto-completion feature, the on-the-fly javadoc parsing (and display of it when using the auto-completion feature), and the advantage that it uses its own compiler and therefore provides much more flexibility than if it were to use javac, for example. Also, the compilation-upon-file-save feature is very useful in my opinion, along with the red (upon error) / yellow (upon warning) underlining in the file. I know other IDEs, like Netbeans, which have very similar features, but I’m quite sure that IDEA doesn’t have all these (if any at all). In addition to that, eclipse is very light-weight in comparison and provides many advantages if you program other languages as well, since with a simple plugin, full support for that language would be integrated. I, for one, use eclipse for developing C/C++ for the reasons above AND because unlike any other C IDEs I know of, eclipse doesn’t force you to use a certain (and possibly outdated) compiler and instead lets you choose the one of your preference.[/quote]Ahahahahahahaha ur such a fukken idiot, IDEA has everything you mentioned and a lot more. item.title: Ultimate Newbie Question
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:19, topic:339657”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=436035.msg3203373#msg3203373 date=1273539733]

[quote author=Ollie link=topic=436035.msg3203315#msg3203315 date=1273536522]

[quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=436035.msg3203300#msg3203300 date=1273534893]

Blame eclipse for sucking, use IDEA
[/quote]shoot yourself

? IDEA > Eclipse
[/quote]how exactly
[/quote]By not having 500 half-assed, badly implemented plugins, but instead having nearly all extra content officially updated by Jetbrains to comform to high usage standards.[/quote]Any plugins you don’t like can be disabled. Personally, I used IDEA for about an hour until I came to the conclusion that it was very similar to JCreator (which I used for like 6 months) and dropped it. As opposed to IDEA, eclipse is 100% open source (unlike the ‘ultimate edition’ for idea) and contains integrated features that just completely eliminate IDEA from the competition. The method/variable auto-completion feature, the on-the-fly javadoc parsing (and display of it when using the auto-completion feature), and the advantage that it uses its own compiler and therefore provides much more flexibility than if it were to use javac, for example. Also, the compilation-upon-file-save feature is very useful in my opinion, along with the red (upon error) / yellow (upon warning) underlining in the file. I know other IDEs, like Netbeans, which have very similar features, but I’m quite sure that IDEA doesn’t have all these (if any at all). In addition to that, eclipse is very light-weight in comparison and provides many advantages if you program other languages as well, since with a simple plugin, full support for that language would be integrated. I, for one, use eclipse for developing C/C++ for the reasons above AND because unlike any other C IDEs I know of, eclipse doesn’t force you to use a certain (and possibly outdated) compiler and instead lets you choose the one of your preference.

item.title: Ultimate Newbie Question
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Play icon on the toolbar will generally run the last project you ran, which in your case is probably some weird project which isn’t there anymore.

Save (hit ctrl+s), then right click on the “ello” project (or the one your hello_world.java belongs to), and choose “run”. It might ask you whether you want to run it as an applet, as an application, etc. Choose Java application. And if you’re lucky it will work.

Note that hello_world.java is a particularly strange name for a Java file / class, but that’s certainly not causing your particular problem.

Read full topic
